Detailed Description

The Japanese transcoder converts text stored in UCS-2, JIS, S-JIS and EUC to and from each of the formats. It also features autodetection of the type of encoding used within a text.

NOTICE: Some code is taken from the book CJKV Information Processing by Ken Lunde (O'Reilly, October 2002. ISBN 1-56592-224-7), and its accompanying web- and ftp sites. Specifically, code from the book is used in the following methods: Autodetection of encoding type S-JIS to JIS conversion JIS to S-JIS conversion (Please do not remove this notice, as it is required for using code from the book).

Member Function Documentation

Vector< UINT8 > JapaneseTranscoder::Convert (  const UINT8 *  text,
INT  text_len,
EncodingType  to_encoding,
BOOLEAN *  success = 0,
EncodingType  from_encoding = Auto
)  const
 

Converts a text from one encoding to another. All text encodings enumerated in EncodingType can be converted to one another.

Parameters:
text the original text
text_len the length of the original text
to_encoding target encoding
success optional output parameter is TRUE if converting was successful
from_encoding specifies the encoding of the original text. Per default this is set to Auto, which causes the method to auto-detect the encoding type
Returns:
a Vector of UINT8 containing the converted text. A Vector was chosen for the return data because it offers a buffer of variable length which does not change the byte order on LE/BE architectures. Variable length is needed because one can never tell how long a converted text is going to be, which would be necessary for e.g. a byte buffer of UINT8 data. WStrings change order of bytes on reading the data (WCHAR is changed according to LE/BE architecture).
